We may now prove Theorem 2. 
Rather than carry out a series of standard constructions,  it will be sufficient to outline the general procedure.  As a first step,  let the boundary values / ( which are by hypothesis of class C^ on Г ) be extended to a function,  still denoted by /,  of class C^ in £ ".  Next approximate / by a sequence of C^ functions / ^ which converge to / in the C^ topology in some domain containing the closure of D,  Also let D be approximated by a sequence of domains D^ whose boundaries are of class C^,  in such a way that the associated quantities ^^,  K^^ and H^ converge to ^,  K,  and H as D^ tends to D,  According to the hypothesis of Theorem 2,  then,  it is apparent that there exists an integer Mq such that

This being the case.  Lemma 4 implies the existence of a solution u^ of the minimal surface equation in D^ which takes the boundary values / ^ on Г^.  Moreover,  for all sufficiently large m we have \4 u^\ < il / + 1,  where M denotes the quantity on the right hand side of ( 13 ). 
By standard techniques in the theory of elliptic equations,  the sequence { 11^ } converges to a unique solution of the minimal surface equation in D which takes the boundary values / on Г,  Since the constructions outlined above can be assumed known,  and since solutions are obviously unique,  this completes the proof of Theorem 2.
